Found the answer.

ASP.NET doesn't fallback properly to the parent language. If it cannot recognize the file as a "fallback" locale then it fails to parse it, and shows the misleading error.

e.g. 

    ContosoGrobber.resx
    ContosoGrobber.en-us.resx

works fine. But: 

    ContosoGrobber.resx
    ContosoGrobber.en.resx

fails when the locale string `en` isn't recognized. Changing it to use the full locale name, and avoid the buggy fallback code is the fix. e.g.:


    ContosoGrobber.qps.resx

should become:

    ContosoGrobber.qps-ploc.resx

Found the answer.

ASP.NET doesn't fallback properly to the parent language. If it cannot recognize the file as a "fallback" locale then it fails to parse it, and shows the misleading error.

e.g. 

    ContosoGrobber.resx
    ContosoGrobber.en-us.resx

works fine. But: 

    ContosoGrobber.resx
    ContosoGrobber.en.resx

fails when the **"`en`"** portion of the locale string isn't recognized. Changing it to use the full locale name, and avoid the buggy fallback code is the fix. e.g.:


    ContosoGrobber.qps.resx

should become:

    ContosoGrobber.qps-ploc.resx


-----------

In other words: if a browser is requesting locale `qps-ploc`, **ideally** you could use

    ContosoGrobber.qps.resx

and the local [`qps-ploc`](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/dd319106(v=vs.85).aspx) will fallback to `qps`. But because of the bug in ASP.NET it doesn't fallback correctly. This means you cannot *let* it fallback; you have to actually handle all possible locales:

    ContosoGrobber.qps-ploc.resx
    ContosoGrobber.qps-plocm.resx
    ContosoGrobber.qps-ploca.resx
